On 12 March the SMM’s mandate was extended to 31 March 2016 by a consen-sus decision of the OSCE’s 57 participating States. The decision allows for the number of SMM monitors to be increased up to 1,000, as necessary.

SMM Chief Monitor Apakan thanked all participating States for their continued support for the Mission and said that the SMM is now able to continue to play its important role in assisting Ukraine to achieve peace and stability.

On 18-19 March Apakan visited Mariupol. There, he visited one of the main ob-servation points to assess the situation in and around Shyrokyne. He also met the SMM team working in Mariupol as well as the city’s Mayor.

The ceasefire in eastern Ukraine is largely holding but there continue to be viola-tions in and around Donetsk airport and Shyrokyne.

On 23 March Apakan called on all sides to declare a temporary truce in order to allow for the provision of humanitarian aid and access by OSCE monitors into Shyrokyne.

On 24-25 March the Deputy Chief Monitor is traveling to Shyrokyne to assess the general security situation, facilitate access for OSCE monitors to the east of Shy-rokyne and encourage parties to de-escalate tensions.

The SMM is restrained in fulfilling its monitoring functions by restrictions imposed by third parties and security considerations including the lack of information on the whereabouts of landmines.
